ques: I'd like a _______ of milk, please

I'd like some _______ toast, please

_______ days we go out for lunch at about 12:30

They asked almost _______ of the questions in the book

How long have you lived _______ New York?
explanation: "Glass" is the correct option because it is common to ask for a glass of milk. "Cup" is typically used for hot beverages like tea or coffee.
"Some" is the correct option as it is used to offer or ask for an indefinite quantity of something.
"Which" is the correct option because it is used to ask about one or more items from a definite set.
"Look" is the correct option because it fits the sentence structure indicating the appearance of familiarity.
"Rather" is the correct option because it expresses a preference.
"Mind" is the correct option as it is used to ask if someone has an objection.
"Left" is the correct option as it indicates position or direction.
"Matter" is the correct option because it is used to express indifference.
"A cup" is the correct option because it is common to serve tea in a cup.
"Few" is the correct option as it refers to a small number of books.
"In the middle" is the correct prepositional phrase indicating position.
"On the right" is the correct prepositional phrase indicating position.
"In a few minutes" is the correct prepositional phrase indicating time.
"Over there" is the correct phrase indicating location.
"On the left" is the correct prepositional phrase indicating position.
"With" is the correct preposition for indicating conversation with someone.
"Fluently" is the correct adverb indicating a high level of skill in speaking French.
"Often" is the correct adverb indicating frequency.
"Extremely" is the correct adverb indicating a high degree of skill.
"Trouble" is the correct noun indicating difficulties or problems.
"Mistakes" is the correct noun referring to errors. The sentence means he makes several errors in Russian.
"A lot of" is the correct phrase indicating a significant amount of trouble with spelling.
"Pronunciation" is the correct noun referring to the way in which a word is spoken. The sentence means her pronunciation is very good.
"Once in a while" is the correct phrase indicating infrequency. The sentence means I speak German occasionally.
"Native" is the correct adjective indicating the first language learned. The sentence means Spanish is George's first language.
"Accent" is the correct noun referring to the way someone pronounces words. The sentence means I speak English with a Greek pronunciation.
"Understands" is the correct verb indicating comprehension. The sentence means Paul comprehends Japanese.
"Read" is the correct verb indicating the ability to interpret written text. The sentence means they can interpret Italian text very well.
"A little" is the correct phrase indicating a small amount. The sentence means he speaks a small amount of Spanish.
"Pretty" is the correct adverb indicating a moderate degree. The sentence means we understand Arabic moderately well.
"His" is the correct possessive pronoun indicating ownership. The sentence means he is writing to a friend of his.
"Hers" is the correct possessive pronoun indicating ownership. The sentence means Martha is a good friend of hers.
"Theirs" is the correct possessive pronoun indicating ownership. The sentence means those people are friends of theirs.
"Yours" is the correct possessive pronoun indicating ownership. The sentence means here is a friend of yours.
"Ours" is the correct possessive pronoun indicating ownership. The sentence means Bill is an old friend of ours.
"Looking at" is the correct phrasal verb indicating the act of directing one's gaze towards something. The sentence means what are you directing your gaze towards?
"Too" is the correct adverb indicating inclusion. The sentence means do you also want to go with them?
"To" is the correct preposition indicating direction. The sentence means he is writing a message directed to a friend of his.
"Just" is the correct adverb indicating the present moment. The sentence means we are currently talking to Mr. Sullivan.
"Anything" is the correct pronoun indicating an indefinite object. The sentence means I do not want any object or thing at the present moment.
"By the way" is a phrase used to introduce a new topic or to ask for additional information. The sentence means "By the way, who are you waiting for?"
"Something" is the correct option because it indicates that she is engaged in an activity at the moment.
"Sure" is the correct option as it indicates uncertainty about the correct time. The sentence means "I'm not certain of the correct time."
"Either" is the correct option because it is used to agree with a negative statement. The sentence means "Leo isn't certain either."
"At the moment" is the correct phrase indicating the present time. The sentence means "They're thinking about the geography lesson currently."
"Absolutely" is the correct adverb emphasizing certainty. The sentence means "She's not completely sure what time she'll come back."
"For" is the correct preposition indicating purpose. The sentence means "Are you waiting for the teacher?"
"In" is the correct preposition indicating age range. The sentence means "Is Mr. Jones in his sixties?"
"Quite" is the correct adverb indicating the degree. The sentence means "My sister is not quite fifteen."
"Guess" is the correct verb indicating estimation. The sentence means "Guess how old he is."
"About" is the correct adverb indicating approximation. The sentence means "I'd say she's approximately fifty."
"Last" is the correct adjective indicating the most recent. The sentence means "How old was he on his most recent birthday?"
"His" is the correct possessive pronoun indicating ownership. The sentence means "John is in his teens."
"Next" is the correct adjective indicating the upcoming one. The sentence means "He's going to be thirty-nine on his next birthday."
"Youngest" is the correct adjective indicating the one with the least age. The sentence means "I'm the youngest in my family."
"Altogether" is the correct adverb indicating the total number. The sentence means "There are eight of us in total."
"Many" is the correct determiner indicating quantity. The sentence means "How many are there in your class?"
"What age" is the correct phrase indicating a request for specific information about age. The sentence means "We'd like to know what age he is."
"Next to" is the correct phrase indicating the position relative to others. The sentence means "She's the one right before the youngest in our class."
"About" is the correct preposition indicating approximation. The sentence means "I go to bed at approximately midnight."
"Usually" is the correct adverb indicating a habitual action. The sentence means "He usually has orange juice every day."
"Wakes" is the correct verb indicating the action of getting up. The sentence means "Frank wakes up at 7 o'clock on Monday."
"The telephone" is the correct noun indicating the device used for communication. The sentence means "We talk on the telephone every day."
"Eating" is the correct verb indicating the action of consuming food. The sentence means "They finish eating at 8:30 p.m."
"Television" is the correct noun indicating the device used for watching shows. The sentence means "We watch television much later than you do."
"The radio" is the correct noun indicating the device used for listening to programs. The sentence means "After dinner, they listen to the radio for a while."
"Breakfast" is the correct noun indicating the morning meal. The sentence means "She has breakfast at the same time every day."
"Light" is the correct adjective indicating a small or not heavy meal. The sentence means "My uncle has a light lunch on Tuesday."
"Buttered" is the correct adjective indicating toast with butter on it. The sentence means "I'd like some buttered toast, please."
"Until" is the correct preposition indicating the time up to which he works. The sentence means "Sometimes, he works until 9:45 p.m."
"Some" is the correct adjective indicating an indefinite quantity of days. The sentence means "Some days we go out for lunch at about 12:30."
"Until" is the correct preposition indicating the time up to which she worked. The sentence means "She worked from early morning until late at night."
"Around" is the correct preposition indicating an approximate time. The sentence means "It is around one o'clock."
"Immediately" is the correct adverb indicating the action happening without delay. The sentence means "They went home immediately after work."
"Noon" is the correct noun indicating 12:00 p.m. The sentence means "Jonathan was here at noon for lunch."
"Close" is the correct adjective indicating proximity to a certain time. The sentence means "We went to bed close to 11:30 p.m."
"Soundly" is the correct adverb indicating a good quality of sleep. The sentence means "Did you sleep soundly last night?"
"Day" is the correct noun indicating the entire period of daylight. The sentence means "I read books and magazines all day yesterday."
"Sharp" is the correct adjective indicating exactly at the stated time. The sentence means "She was here at ten o'clock sharp."
"Sort" is the correct noun indicating a type or kind. The sentence means "What sort of lunch do you want?"
"Woke" is the correct verb indicating the action of getting up from sleep. The sentence means "He woke up late yesterday."
"O'clock" is the correct noun indicating the hour of the day. The sentence means "I'll meet you at exactly two o'clock."
"Wife" is the correct noun indicating the speaker's spouse. The sentence means "My wife makes breakfast for our daughters."
"Subjects" is the correct noun indicating the topics of conversation. The sentence means "What subjects did you talk about yesterday?"
"If" is the correct conjunction used to introduce a question. The sentence means "I asked him if he knew Jim Stone."
"Did" is the correct auxiliary verb used to form the past tense question. The sentence means "Where did you go last week?"
"Lot of" is the correct phrase indicating a large quantity. The sentence means "We saw a lot of things there."
"Different" is the correct adjective indicating a variety. The sentence means "They answered several different questions."
"Didn't" is the correct contraction of "did not" used to form a negative sentence. The sentence means "Nancy said she'd rather have tea if I didn't mind."
"On" is the correct preposition used in the phrase "call on" meaning to visit. The sentence means "We went to call on a friend last night."
"Single" is the correct adjective indicating each one individually. The sentence means "I answered every single one of those questions."
"Visited" is the correct verb indicating the action of going to see someone. The sentence means "Jim visited Ed in the hospital last year."
"A few" is the correct phrase indicating a small number. The sentence means "He knew a few of those people."
"Before" is the correct preposition indicating the day preceding yesterday. The sentence means "She made breakfast the day before yesterday."
"All" is the correct pronoun indicating the entirety. The sentence means "They asked almost all of the questions in the book."
"Finally" is the correct adverb indicating the end of a process. The sentence means "Finally, I said I'd come."
"Nearly" is the correct adverb indicating an approximate time. The sentence means "It is nearly six o'clock."
"Close" is the correct adjective indicating proximity in time. The sentence means "She leaves the office close to seven o'clock."
"Every" is the correct adjective indicating all instances. The sentence means "They dressed every morning."
"Friend" is the correct noun indicating a person with whom one has a bond of mutual affection. The sentence means "John has an interesting friend."
"Used" is the correct verb indicating a habitual action in the past. The sentence means "We used to go to the movies with them all the time."
"Rarely" is the correct adverb indicating infrequency. The sentence means "I rarely have time to read."
"Companions" is the correct noun indicating friends or associates. The sentence means "That young boy has many companions."
"Watch" is the correct verb indicating the action of viewing. The sentence means "You almost always watch television."
"Quite" is the correct adverb indicating a significant degree. The sentence means "Jack goes to work quite early in the morning."
"On" is the correct preposition indicating location along a street. The sentence means "I live on Washington Street."
"At" is the correct preposition indicating a specific address. The sentence means "Mr. Smith lives at 1203 Washington Street."
"On" is the correct preposition indicating location along a boulevard. The sentence means "My brother lives on Jones Boulevard."
"On" is the correct preposition indicating location along a drive. The sentence means "My father and mother live on University Drive."
"At" is the correct preposition indicating a specific address. The sentence means "Do you live at 9601 Miller Lane?"
"To" is the correct preposition indicating direction towards a destination. The sentence means "I go to the movies every week."
"In" is the correct preposition indicating location within a city. The sentence means "You live here in the city, don't you?"
"To" is the correct preposition indicating direction towards a destination. The sentence means "Are you going to the restaurant?"
"To" and "on" are the correct prepositions indicating direction towards a destination and location along a street. The sentence means "Yes. I'm going to the restaurant on Washington Street."
"In" is the correct preposition indicating location within a city. The sentence means "How long have you lived in New York?"
